Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a LC/MS/MS for Multidisciplinary Environmental Studies and Training at Tennessee State University

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: An instrument that pairs liquid chromatography with triple quadrupole mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) has the capability to analyze multiple compounds and their chemical structures in complex mixtures. Acquisition of such an instrument enables fundamental multidisciplinary research at Tennessee State University by researchers from environmental engineering, chemistry, food science, soil science, and biology. Key research activities include efforts to advance knowledge on: 1) degradation products of insecticides in the environment, 2) water treatment processes to remove pharmaceuticals, 3) processes that degrade toxins in water, 4) absorption of insecticides by nursery pests, and 5) pesticide residues in engineered food. The instrumentation will become a key element of TSUâ€™s research infrastructure. The LC-MS/MS will be used in undergraduate and graduate courses and will promote partnerships and collaborative activities with surrounding universities and research centers.<br/><br/>This advanced LC-MS/MS instrumentation consists a triple quadrupole analyzer with a mass range up to 3,000 m/z and a detection limit of ng/l level. This capability will allow environmental engineering researchers to determine seven neonicotinoid residues and possible degradation products in soil and water, enabling discovery of the fate and transport of neonicotinoids in the environment. Researchers will monitor emerging contaminants, including perfluorinated compounds in groundwater, cyanotoxins in surface waters, and residuals of pharmaceuticals and personal care products in wastewater, improving understanding of the effect of degradation processes due to biodegradation, photolysis, and hydrolysis on the behavior of emerging contaminants. The LC-MS/MS will be used to characterize the residual analysis of insecticides in the development of effective treatment methods of soil and container media for nursery pests including Chrysobothris, Japanese beetle, and fire ants. The LC-MS/MS will allow food science researchers to characterize the structure and functionality change of bioactive polysaccharides to learn more about the stability and shelf life of engineered food. Researchers in agriculture will use the equipment to study complex pesticide residues.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A liquid chromatography paired with triple quadrupole mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) has been purchased and installed at the Environmental Laboratory at Tennessee State University. The acquisition of this instrument is to analyze multiple compounds and their chemical structures in complex mixtures. The advantage of triple quadrupole MS is the greatly increased specificity of the analysis over single stage mass analysis. This tandem technique of the LC-MS/MS can analyze biochemical, organic, and inorganic compounds commonly found in complex samples of environmental contaminants.

 

It is the first time TSU to have a mass spectrometry function for analysis degradation products in the College of Engineering. The MRI instrument LC-MS/MS acquired through this grant significantly enhanced the sample analytical capability of TSU. capacity of this instrument makes it possible to measure the concentrations of environmental samples and chemical structure of the samples. The results from all the research groups have strong impacts the knowledge and knowhow of the contemporary sciences and technologies, as manifested in the publications and presentations made by the investigators of the research groups who used the LC-MS/MS in the characterization of their samples. The environmental laboratory that houses the LC-MS/MS instrument has become an institutional resource that all research groups at TSU can access and utilize the instrument for research and development activities.

 

During the award period, three faculty members, one postdoctoral researcher, and seven graduate students have been trained in the use and application of LC-MS/MS instrument. More than eight faculty members, two postdoctoral researchers, twenty graduate students and twelve undergraduate students have been involved in research activities that used LC-MS/MS for sample characterization. The results have been disseminated to scientific communities through manuscripts in professional journals and presentations at national and international conferences. These publications and presentations were results of research activities that involved the use of the LC-MS/MS instrument for sample characterization.
